articles.headline: U.S. Military Faces Reality in Gaza as Aid Project Struggles
articles.snippet: The Pentagon predicted that a stream of humanitarian aid would be arriving in Gaza via the floating pier, but little relief has reached the besieged strip, officials acknowledged this week.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon predicted that a stream of humanitarian aid would be arriving in Gaza via the floating pier, but little relief has reached the besieged strip, officials acknowledged this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the week since the U.S. military and allies attached a temporary pier to the Gaza shoreline, Pentagon planners have come face to face with the logistical nightmare that critics had warned would accompany the endeavor.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Decades in the Making, a New Era Dawns for the N.C.A.A.: Paying Athletes Directly
articles.snippet: If approved by a judge, the $2.8 billion settlement of an antitrust lawsuit would allow for the first revenue-sharing plan for college athletes. The question now: How will it work?
articles.abstract: If approved by a judge, the $2.8 billion settlement of an antitrust lawsuit would allow for the first revenue-sharing plan for college athletes. The question now: How will it work?
articles.lead_paragraph: Since its founding, the N.C.A.A. has operated with a business model that defined the college athlete as an amateur. Over the years, as college sports evolved into a mega-enterprise, lawsuits and labor actions chipped away at that model, which came to be increasingly seen as exploitative in big-money sports like football and men’s basketball.

articles.headline: China Has a Plan for Its Housing Crisis. Here’s Why It’s Not Enough.
articles.snippet: A new approach by China’s top leaders is bold but pales against the problem: a vast number of empty apartments no one wants to buy.
articles.abstract: A new approach by China’s top leaders is bold but pales against the problem: a vast number of empty apartments no one wants to buy.
articles.lead_paragraph: China has a housing problem. A very big one. It has nearly four million apartments that no one wants to buy, a combined expanse of unwanted living space roughly the area of Philadelphia.

articles.headline: A Lender to Consumer Start-Ups Falters, Rattling Its Clients
articles.snippet: Ampla, which lent money to smaller businesses that sold clothing, home furnishings and other items directly to consumers, is struggling financially and seeking a buyer.
articles.abstract: Ampla, which lent money to smaller businesses that sold clothing, home furnishings and other items directly to consumers, is struggling financially and seeking a buyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: A popular lender backed by venture capital firms is struggling financially, sending shock waves through the small clothing and home furnishing companies that count on its financing.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Ramps Up Anti-Biden Posts on X
articles.snippet: The billionaire owner of X has increasingly been using his social media platform to criticize President Biden for his health and immigration policies, according to a New York Times analysis.
articles.abstract: The billionaire owner of X has increasingly been using his social media platform to criticize President Biden for his health and immigration policies, according to a New York Times analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Elon Musk posted on X that President Biden “obviously barely knows what’s going on.”
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: As Rafah Offensive Grinds On, Hunger in Gaza Spirals
articles.snippet: Aid officials and health experts expect famine this month unless Israel lifts barriers to aid, the fighting stops and vital services are restored.
articles.abstract: Aid officials and health experts expect famine this month unless Israel lifts barriers to aid, the fighting stops and vital services are restored.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, the Gaza Strip’s southernmost city, Rafah, was one of the few places where desperate Gazans could find some aid and food. Bakeries sold bread; fuel powered generators; markets were open, if expensive.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Bilal Shbair and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

articles.headline: The Capital of Women’s Soccer
articles.snippet: The success of Barcelona’s team has made Catalonia a laboratory for finding out what happens when the women’s game has prominence similar to the men’s.
articles.abstract: The success of Barcelona’s team has made Catalonia a laboratory for finding out what happens when the women’s game has prominence similar to the men’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little more than an hour before the game begins, the gates outside the Johan Cruyff Stadium swing open and a thousand or so fans rush inside. Some scurry to the turnstiles. Others wait patiently at the merchandise stalls, anxious to buy a jersey, a scarf, a commemorative trinket.
articles.byline: By Rory Smith and María Garrido
